text: Which peace treaty of 1648 established the principle of 'cuius regio, eius religio' and is considered the foundation of the modern nation-state system?
explanation: The Peace of Westphalia (1648) ended the Thirty Years' War and established key principles of state sovereignty.
detailedExplanation: The Peace of Westphalia, signed in 1648, consisted of two treaties that ended the Thirty Years' War in the Holy Roman Empire and the Eighty Years' War between Spain and the Dutch Republic. It established the principle of state sovereignty and non-interference in domestic affairs, effectively creating the modern international system. The treaty reinforced the 'cuius regio, eius religio' principle, allowing rulers to determine their territory's religion, and marked the decline of religious wars in Europe.

text: The Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) divided newly discovered lands between which two colonial powers along a meridian 370 leagues west of which island group?
options: Spain and Portugal; Cape Verde Islands
explanation: The Treaty of Tordesillas divided the New World between Spain and Portugal along a line 370 leagues west of the Cape Verde Islands.
detailedExplanation: The Treaty of Tordesillas, signed on June 7, 1494, was an agreement between the crowns of Spain and Portugal to divide newly discovered lands outside Europe between them. The treaty established a meridian 370 leagues west of the Cape Verde Islands as the dividing line. Lands to the west would belong to Spain, while lands to the east would belong to Portugal. This division significantly impacted colonial expansion and explains why Brazil became Portuguese while most of South America became Spanish territory.

text: Which article of the Treaty of Versailles specifically assigned full war guilt to Germany and its allies, becoming known as the 'War Guilt Clause'?
explanation: Article 231, known as the War Guilt Clause, placed full responsibility for WWI on Germany and its allies.
detailedExplanation: Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles, signed in 1919, became infamous as the 'War Guilt Clause.' It stated that Germany and its allies were responsible for all loss and damage suffered by the Allied powers during World War I. This article provided the legal basis for demanding reparations from Germany and was deeply resented by the German population. The clause contributed to economic hardship and political instability in Germany, and many historians argue it helped create conditions that led to World War II.
citationTitle: Wikipedia: Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles

text: The Camp David Accords of 1978 were negotiated between which three leaders, resulting in a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel?
explanation: President Jimmy Carter mediated between Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat at Camp David.
detailedExplanation: The Camp David Accords were signed on September 17, 1978, following thirteen days of secret negotiations at Camp David between U.S. President Jimmy Carter, Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin, and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat. The accords led to the Egypt-Israel Peace Treaty of 1979, the first peace agreement between Israel and an Arab country. Egypt recognized Israel's right to exist, while Israel agreed to withdraw from the Sinai Peninsula. Both Begin and Sadat were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for their efforts.

text: The Congress of Vienna (1814-1815) was guided by which principle, aimed at preventing any single European power from dominating the continent?
explanation: The Balance of Power principle guided the Congress of Vienna to prevent any single nation from achieving European hegemony.
detailedExplanation: The Congress of Vienna, held from 1814 to 1815 after Napoleon's defeat, was guided by the principle of Balance of Power. This concept aimed to prevent any single European power from becoming dominant enough to threaten others, as Napoleon had done. The congress, led by figures like Metternich, Castlereagh, and Talleyrand, redrew the map of Europe and established a system of alliances and territorial arrangements designed to maintain equilibrium. This system largely succeeded in preventing major European wars for nearly a century until World War I.

text: Which 1925 treaty, signed in a German city, temporarily stabilized post-WWI Europe by guaranteeing Germany's western borders but notably excluded its eastern frontiers?
explanation: The Locarno Treaties of 1925 guaranteed Germany's western borders with France and Belgium but deliberately excluded eastern borders.
detailedExplanation: The Locarno Treaties, signed in Locarno, Switzerland, in October 1925, were a series of agreements that aimed to secure peace in Western Europe. The main treaty guaranteed Germany's western borders with France and Belgium, with Britain and Italy as guarantors. However, Germany's eastern borders with Poland and Czechoslovakia were deliberately excluded from these guarantees, creating an asymmetry that would prove problematic. The treaties led to Germany's admission to the League of Nations and created the 'Spirit of Locarno,' a period of improved international relations that lasted until the early 1930s.

text: The Good Friday Agreement (1998) established power-sharing in Northern Ireland and included which innovative principle regarding Irish unity?
options: Unity only through simultaneous referendums in both North and South
Gradual transfer of counties based on local votes
explanation: The Good Friday Agreement requires simultaneous majority consent in both Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland for reunification.
detailedExplanation: The Good Friday Agreement (Belfast Agreement) of 1998 established a complex framework for peace in Northern Ireland after decades of conflict. One of its key innovations was the principle of consent regarding Irish unity - it stipulated that Northern Ireland would remain part of the United Kingdom unless and until a majority in Northern Ireland votes otherwise. Crucially, it also required that any change in status would need simultaneous consent through referendums in both Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. This dual consent mechanism was designed to ensure that reunification could only occur with the agreement of people on both sides of the border.

text: Which Cold War-era treaty of 1987 was the first to eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons and included unprecedented on-site verification procedures?
explanation: The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty eliminated all intermediate-range missiles and featured groundbreaking verification measures.
detailedExplanation: The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty, signed by Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev in December 1987, was revolutionary in nuclear disarmament. It eliminated an entire class of nuclear weapons - all ground-launched ballistic and cruise missiles with ranges between 500 and 5,500 kilometers. The treaty was notable for its comprehensive verification regime, including on-site inspections, continuous monitoring at missile production facilities, and short-notice inspections. Over 2,600 missiles were destroyed under the treaty. The agreement marked a significant thaw in Cold War relations and demonstrated that meaningful nuclear disarmament was possible.

text: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (1918) allowed Germany to transfer how many divisions from the Eastern to Western Front, significantly impacting the final phase of World War I?
explanation: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk freed up 44 German divisions for transfer to the Western Front.
detailedExplanation: Signed on March 3, 1918, the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk ended Russia's participation in World War I and allowed Germany to relocate 44 divisions from the Eastern Front to launch their final Spring Offensive on the Western Front. This massive troop transfer gave Germany temporary numerical superiority in the west, but the offensive ultimately failed, and these same troops were exhausted when the Allies launched their Hundred Days Offensive later that year.

text: Which unusual provision was included in the 1783 Treaty of Paris that ended the American Revolutionary War, granting Americans specific rights in British territories?
explanation: The Treaty of Paris granted Americans perpetual fishing rights in the Grand Banks off Newfoundland.
detailedExplanation: The 1783 Treaty of Paris contained a remarkable provision that granted American fishermen the right to fish in the Grand Banks off Newfoundland and in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence, as well as to dry fish on unsettled shores of Nova Scotia and Labrador. This was crucial for the New England economy and remained a contentious issue in Anglo-American relations for decades, contributing to tensions that led to the War of 1812.

text: The Portsmouth Peace Treaty of 1905, which earned Theodore Roosevelt the Nobel Peace Prize, was negotiated to end which conflict?
explanation: The Treaty of Portsmouth ended the Russo-Japanese War, with Roosevelt mediating between Russia and Japan.
detailedExplanation: Signed on September 5, 1905, in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, this treaty ended the Russo-Japanese War. President Theodore Roosevelt's successful mediation between Russia and Japan made him the first American to win the Nobel Peace Prize in 1906. The treaty recognized Japan's predominant interests in Korea, transferred the Liaodong Peninsula lease to Japan, and ceded the southern half of Sakhalin Island to Japan, marking Russia's first major military defeat by an Asian power.

text: The Dayton Agreement of 1995 established what percentage division of territory between the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Republika Srpska?
explanation: The Dayton Agreement allocated 51% of Bosnia's territory to the Federation and 49% to Republika Srpska.
detailedExplanation: The Dayton Agreement, signed on December 14, 1995, ended the Bosnian War by dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina into two main entities: the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (predominantly Bosniak and Croat) receiving 51% of the territory, and Republika Srpska (predominantly Serb) receiving 49%. This carefully negotiated territorial division was designed to reflect demographic realities while ensuring the viability of both entities within a single sovereign state.

text: Which Byzantine Emperor signed the Treaty of Devol in 1108, agreeing to become a vassal of the Norman Prince Bohemond I of Antioch before later repudiating it?
explanation: Emperor Alexios I Komnenos signed the Treaty of Devol in 1108 but never implemented its terms.
detailedExplanation: The Treaty of Devol was signed in 1108 between Byzantine Emperor Alexios I Komnenos and Bohemond I of Antioch, ending their conflict that arose from the First Crusade. Under the treaty's terms, Bohemond would hold Antioch as a fief from the Byzantine Emperor and provide military service. However, Bohemond died in 1111 without returning to the East, and his nephew Tancred, who ruled Antioch as regent, completely ignored the treaty's provisions, making it essentially meaningless.

text: The Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact's secret protocol divided Poland along which river, fundamentally altering the geopolitical landscape of Eastern Europe?
explanation: The secret protocol divided Poland along the Bug River between German and Soviet spheres of influence.
detailedExplanation: The Nazi-Soviet Pact signed on August 23, 1939, contained a secret additional protocol that divided Eastern Europe into German and Soviet spheres of influence. The protocol specifically designated the Bug River as the demarcation line for the partition of Poland, with Germany taking the western portion and the Soviet Union the eastern. This agreement directly enabled the joint invasion of Poland in September 1939, triggering World War II and sealing the fate of millions of Poles.

text: The Wuchale Treaty of 1889 between Italy and Ethiopia became controversial due to a discrepancy between the Amharic and Italian versions regarding what issue?
explanation: The Italian version claimed Ethiopia accepted Italian protection, while the Amharic version did not, leading to the First Italo-Ethiopian War.
detailedExplanation: The Treaty of Wuchale, signed on May 2, 1889, between Emperor Menelik II of Ethiopia and Italy, contained a critical mistranslation in Article XVII. The Italian version stated that Ethiopia 'consents to use Italy for all business it does with other European powers,' effectively making Ethiopia an Italian protectorate. However, the Amharic version only stated that Ethiopia 'could' use Italy's services, preserving Ethiopian sovereignty. This discrepancy led to the First Italo-Ethiopian War (1895-1896), which ended with Ethiopia's decisive victory at the Battle of Adwa.

text: The Antarctic Treaty System of 1959 suspended territorial claims for how many years, and what happened when this period expired?
explanation: The Antarctic Treaty suspended territorial claims indefinitely, and the treaty remains in effect with no expiration date.
detailedExplanation: The Antarctic Treaty, signed on December 1, 1959, and entering into force on June 23, 1961, indefinitely suspended all territorial claims in Antarctica and prohibited new claims while the treaty remains in force. Unlike many international agreements, it has no expiration date and continues to govern Antarctica as a scientific preserve and natural reserve. The treaty has been supplemented by the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty (Madrid Protocol) in 1991, further strengthening environmental protections for the continent.

text: The Lateran Treaty of 1929 resolved the 'Roman Question' by creating Vatican City as a sovereign state. What unusual diplomatic privilege did this treaty grant to the Pope that remains unique among world leaders?
options: The right to declare neutrality in all future wars
Immunity from extradition under any circumstances
The ability to issue passports recognized by all Catholic nations
Exclusive jurisdiction over marriage annulments for heads of state
explanation: The Lateran Treaty guaranteed the Pope's right to remain neutral in temporal conflicts and for Vatican City to be recognized as perpetually neutral.
detailedExplanation: The Lateran Treaty, signed between Pope Pius XI and Mussolini's Italy, resolved nearly 60 years of tension following the papal loss of temporal power in 1870. A key provision established Vatican City's perpetual neutrality and the Pope's right to remain neutral in international conflicts. This unique diplomatic status has been respected even during major wars, making the Pope the only head of state with treaty-guaranteed neutrality recognized internationally. The treaty also included a financial settlement of 750 million lire and 1 billion lire in Italian state bonds as compensation for the former Papal States.

text: The Treaty of Küçük Kaynarca (1774) between Russia and the Ottoman Empire contained a clause that would later be used to justify major geopolitical interventions. What significant right did Russia gain over Ottoman subjects?
options: The right to establish Orthodox churches in Ottoman territory
The right to protect all Orthodox Christians in the Ottoman Empire
The right to appoint governors in Moldavia and Wallachia
The right to maintain a naval base in the Black Sea
explanation: Article VII gave Russia the right to protect Orthodox Christians throughout the Ottoman Empire, later used to justify interventions including the Crimean War.
detailedExplanation: The Treaty of Küçük Kaynarca, ending the Russo-Turkish War of 1768-1774, contained Article VII which granted Russia the right to make representations on behalf of Orthodox Christians in the Ottoman Empire and to protect them. This clause was deliberately ambiguous but became a powerful tool of Russian foreign policy. Russia later interpreted this broadly to claim a protectorate over all Orthodox subjects of the Sultan, using it to justify interventions in the Balkans and ultimately contributing to the outbreak of the Crimean War in 1853. The treaty also granted Russia access to the Black Sea and passage through the Bosphorus and Dardanelles, fundamentally shifting the balance of power in Eastern Europe.

text: The Anglo-Irish Agreement of 1985 was signed despite which dramatic protest by Ulster Unionist politicians that lasted for over a year?
options: A complete boycott of Westminster Parliament sessions
Mass resignation from the Northern Ireland Assembly forcing new elections
A general strike that shut down all public services
Occupation of government buildings in Belfast and Stormont
explanation: All 15 Ulster Unionist MPs resigned from Westminster in protest, forcing by-elections to demonstrate opposition to the Agreement.
detailedExplanation: The Anglo-Irish Agreement, signed by Margaret Thatcher and Garret FitzGerald in November 1985, gave the Irish government an advisory role in Northern Ireland affairs for the first time since partition. Ulster Unionists were furious at not being consulted and saw it as a betrayal. In an unprecedented move, all 15 Ulster Unionist MPs resigned their Westminster seats simultaneously in January 1986, forcing by-elections which they fought as a referendum on the Agreement. They also withdrew from local government, leaving many councils unable to function. The protest continued for over a year, with Unionists refusing to work the Agreement, though it remained in force until superseded by the Good Friday Agreement in 1998.

text: The Treaty of Rapallo (1922) between Germany and Soviet Russia shocked the Western Allies because it contained what unprecedented provision that violated post-WWI restrictions?
options: Secret military cooperation allowing German rearmament on Soviet soil
A mutual defense pact against Western intervention
Joint recognition of pre-war territorial boundaries
Immediate diplomatic recognition and renunciation of war reparations
explanation: The treaty established full diplomatic relations and both countries renounced all territorial and financial claims against each other, including German reparations to Russia.
detailedExplanation: The Treaty of Rapallo, signed during the Genoa Conference in April 1922, stunned Western powers because it brought together the two pariah states of post-WWI Europe. Germany and Soviet Russia established full diplomatic relations and renounced all territorial and financial claims stemming from the war and Treaty of Brest-Litovsk. Most significantly, both nations agreed to waive war reparations claims against each other, allowing Germany to avoid paying substantial compensation to Russia. The treaty broke Germany's diplomatic isolation and gave both nations leverage against the Western Allies. While the published treaty was diplomatic, it opened the door to secret military cooperation that would later violate Versailles restrictions, helping Germany develop prohibited weapons and tactics.
